CatDescriptText: Cutline of image published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, November 29, 1952, pg. 13 reads:" Negro Clerks, Cashier Become Fashion on Homewood Avenue- When Donahoe's new store on Homewood Avenue opened its doors this week, six Negroes took jobs in store, thanks to the forward-looking Donahoe Store management and the campaign conducted by the Greater Pittsburgh Improvement League which has also secured jobs for a Negro cashier-clerk at another store, Vilsack-Ray's on the same street. The GPIL has also secured clerk-cashier jobs for Negroes at several other chain stores throughout the city, including the Thorofare Supermarket at the intersections of Lincoln Avenue, Frankstown Avenue and Lowell Street in East Liberty.  In the left picture, Miss Helen Smith, one of the cashiers at the new Donahoe store, the front of which is shown in the second photo, waits on an anonymous white customer, one of the many thousands she serves during the day..."
TitMainTitle: Cashier Helen Smith, waiting on customer in interior of Donahoe's grocery store
